importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: August 2025 saw a 21% increase in retail coffee prices compared to the same month the previous year, highlighting the economic impact of tariffs on consumer spending.
In July 2025, the Trump administration imposed high tariffs on coffee imports, triggering immediate price increases and supply chain disruptions.
In September 2025, a bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' was introduced to exempt coffee products from tariffs, signaling political response to economic pressures.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from July to October 2025 marks the peak of tariff-related price hikes and business responses in the U.S. coffee industry.

keyTakeAways: Trump administration tariffs significantly increased the cost of coffee beans, especially from Brazil (50%), Vietnam (20%), and Colombia (10%).
U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, with Brazil supplying 30.7% of imports, followed by Colombia (18.3%) and Vietnam (6.6%).
Retail coffee prices rose nearly 21% in August 2025, with average restaurant coffee prices reaching $3.52 — 10 cents higher than the previous year.
In Washington, D.C., a hot coffee averaged $4.21 (up 4%) and a cold brew averaged $5.35 (up 3.7%) in August 2025.

Coffee roasters like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting have reported increased costs and are considering diversifying suppliers to mitigate tariff impacts.
A 50% tariff on Brazilian coffee, exacerbated by drought-related supply shortages, has had the most significant impact on businesses.
The average price of a pound of coffee rose from $4 to $6, with a 12-ounce bag increasing by 50 cents to $1.
Small coffee businesses face uncertainty and financial strain due to unpredictable pricing, leading some to question sustainability.
Consumers may shift brands or reduce spending, but coffee remains an affordable luxury, and behavior is unlikely to change drastically.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration imposed high tariffs on coffee imports, directly increasing costs and affecting roasters and consumers.

namedEntities.name: Brazil
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brazil is the largest source of U.S. coffee imports, and the 50% tariff on Brazilian coffee beans has had the most significant impact on prices and supply.

namedEntities.name: Vietnam
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Vietnam supplies 6.6% of U.S. coffee imports and faces a 20% tariff, contributing to rising input costs for roasters.

namedEntities.name: Colombia
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Colombia supplies 18.3% of U.S. coffee imports and is subject to a 10% tariff, adding to the cost of imported beans.

namedEntities.name: Swing’s Coffee Roasters
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This long-standing roaster in Virginia and Washington, D.C., has reported financial strain due to tariffs and higher bean costs, affecting consumer pricing.

namedEntities.name: Vigilante Coffee Company
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This company in California and Maryland imports from Brazil, Indonesia, Ethiopia, and Colombia and has seen bean prices rise from $4 to $6 per pound.

namedEntities.name: Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This Maryland-based roaster avoids Brazilian coffee due to tariffs and has observed increased costs in bean purchases over the past eight months.

namedEntities.name: Qualia Coffee
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sells at farmers’ markets in DC and operates under financial uncertainty due to volatile pricing caused by tariffs and supply disruptions.

namedEntities.name: Don Bacon
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Republican representative from Nebraska who co-introduced the 'No Coffee Tax Act' to exempt coffee from tariffs in September 2025.

namedEntities.name: Ro Khanna
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Democratic representative from California who co-introduced the bipartisan 'No Coffee Tax Act' to protect coffee prices from tariffs.

namedEntities.name: Toast
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Restaurant management software provider that reported a 21% year-over-year price increase in coffee and tracked price changes in D.C. and nationally.

namedEntities.name: National Coffee Association
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides data showing that the U.S. imports over 99% of its coffee, highlighting the country’s dependence on foreign suppliers.

namedEntities.name: UN Comtrade Database
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Source of data on U.S. coffee imports, showing Brazil as the top supplier (30.7%) and other key sources.

namedEntities.name: Conference Board
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Research group whose senior economist, Erin McLaughlin, explains consumer behavior in response to price increases.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration’s imposition of high tariffs—50% on Brazil, 20% on Vietnam, and 10% on Colombia—is driving up the cost of imported coffee beans, leading to a 21% year-over-year increase in retail coffee prices. With the U.S. importing over 99% of its coffee and Brazil being the largest supplier, these tariffs are directly impacting roasters like Swing’s Coffee Roasters, Vigilante Coffee Company, and Celtic Cup Coffee Roasting, who report rising input costs and operational strain. Despite efforts to diversify suppliers and reduce reliance on affected countries, consumers in cities like Washington, D.C. are feeling the pinch, with average coffee prices rising by 3–4%. A bipartisan legislative effort—the 'No Coffee Tax Act' introduced in September—aims to exempt coffee from tariffs. While consumers may shift brands or cut back, coffee remains an affordable luxury, and most are unlikely to abandon consumption habits despite the price hikes.
title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Brewing Trouble for Coffee Roasters
